message: HAPPENING LIVE NOW: Watch me and my colleagues on the House Armed Services Committee markup of the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) all day long! It’s time to fund our National Defense and ensure the best support to our military.

HAPPENING LIVE NOW-Pt. 3: Watch me and my colleagues on the House Armed Services Committee markup of the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) all day long! It’s time to fund our National Defense and ensure the best support to our military. *THIS IS THE THIRD PART TO OUR FULL HEARING*

My Simi Valley Staff attended the weekly Veterans luncheon yesterday. This group of local Veterans meets on Wednesday at various local restaurants around the city to share stories and enjoy time with their fellow veterans. We are lucky to have such great veteran groups like this in our community.

Yesterday, I was honored to meet our 2017 Congressional Art Contest winner, Rachael Tahir! Rachael and her mother traveled to Washington, DC to participate in ceremonies congratulating contest winners from Congressional districts across the country and viewed her winning photograph hanging in the Capitol hallway, where it will stay for an entire year! Rachael is a very bright and talented young woman from Simi Valley. The Congressional Art Competition is a great way for our young artist to compete in a nationally recognized contest that accents the many talents of our young people. Congratulations Rachael!

Thank you to James and Eva Fucich and their family for stopping by my office today in DC! The Fucich family is traveling from Simi Valley and has stopped at many historic sites across the country so far for their summer family vacation. They are here touring DC until heading home for 4th of July! Glad you stopped by!

As we celebrate our nation’s Independence Day, be sure to stay safe when using safe and sane fireworks! Please see below some helpful tips and make sure to leave the illegal firework shows to the pros!
Happy 4TH of July everyone! Always remember, Freedom isn’t free. I hope you have a safe and wonderful day filled with fun and good company.

Yesterday my staff presented certificates of recognition to 2016-2017 outgoing Veteran’s of Foreign Affairs (VFW) Post 6885 Commander, Luis Villegas, for his excellent leadership and hard work. Thank you Luis for all you do for VFW Post 6885. Four other post members were honored for their dedication and commitment to Post 6885 as well. Thank you to Paul Darlin, James Bernardi and Doug Cooper! RJ Kelly was installed along with his new board by Corey McKinney. Congratulations to RJ and the whole board.
Last night Lily and I attended the 4th of July Rodeo! We had a great time celebrating our Independence Day with the community!

Yesterday a member of my staff attended the Commemoration Ceremony at Simi Valley Memorial Park. In attendance was Staff Sergeant Murray Shapiro: Who landed at D-Day plus 3, fought at Huertgen forest, Battle of the Bulge, and the Colmar Pocket. These veterans are great inspirations to all on such an important holiday. Thank you for your service!

Today Lily and I attended the Ground Breaking Ceremony in Palmdale for 56 new homes for veterans. It is great to see so many organizations working together to help our veterans. Thank you to Cal Vet, Homes4Families, The City of Palmdale and Habitat for Humanity and their boards for all you do to provide for the men and women who have selflessly given to our nation. With their help and support veterans and their families will have beautiful homes to live and thrive in  the Antelope Valley. It was great to see representatives from Lockheed Martin and Northrup Grumman who are great supporters of this program  as well. I look forward to celebrating the grand opening at a future date.

Yesterday I attended the swearing in ceremony for the Quartz Hill Chamber of Commerce with LA County Supervisor Kathryn Barger. We are lucky to have organizations like the Chamber of Commerce to help our local businesses by providing resources and guidance. Congratulations to the new team!

Today I hosted an opioid roundtable with representatives from the Los Angeles Sheriff Department Intervention Team, Henry Mayo, and Action Family Foundation. We discussed the opioid problem in Santa Clarita and how the medical, law enforcement, and private sector can continue to work together to address the problem and find solutions.

When I am out in the district or in DC, my time is spent meeting with constituents, listening to their concerns and priorities. This is also the full time job of many of my staff in the district. Due to limited scheduling capabilities, we ask that constituents reach out in advance to fill out a request to meet with me or a member of my staff. We also ask that visitors respect other businesses in our buildings by not using signs or chanting. Thank you.
Today would have been Nancy Reagan's 96th birthday. Mrs. Reagan served our country as First Lady with poise and graciousness. Let's honor her legacy.

Today the Plasschaert Family visited my office and took a tour of the Capitol! The family is visiting from Santa Clarita. They have been in New York for their son as he represents the FarWest regional team in the baseball 2017 USSSA All American Games and decided to take the trip south to DC for a few days! Thanks for stopping by!

As a member of congress, one of the great honors I have appointing young constituents to our Nation’s various military academies. Isaac Barcelona, a member of my district staff, has visited these academies and learned how we can best serve the students in the 25th District that want to attend.  He visited the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis, Maryland. Thank you to the USNA for everything you are doing to keep America safe and strong by preparing our best and brightest to take up the torch of leadership and for giving us the opportunity to see some of what you have to deal with on a daily basis in order to accomplish your mission.
Interested in working for the Federal Aviation Administration? The FAA is now accepting applications for entry-level air traffic controller positions. Please follow the link below to apply!

Today, my bill, the Saint Francis Dam Disaster National Memorial Act passed unanimously from the House! I am very thankful for the support the 25th district has received from my colleagues across the country regarding this tragedy. I look forward to future movement of the bill through the Senate.

Yesterday at the Antelope Valley Hispanic Chamber attendees heard an update from our local law enforcement. Capt. Kneer from the Palmdale Sheriff’s Station, Capt. Eric Broneer from the Antelope Valley CHP Office and Capt. Todd Weber of the Lancaster Sheriff’s Station were on hand to answer questions as well as share some of the programs available to the community. The trio spoke about issues like distracted driving, opioid use and how law enforcement works with cities and the county to better our valley. I want to extend my thanks to all of the men and women of law enforcement and their families for putting their lives on the line every day.

Thanks to the Crawford family for stopping by my DC office yesterday before your Capitol tour! They have traveled from Santa Clarita for a family vacation to learn more about our nation’s history. I hope you enjoy your time here in DC!

This morning I participated in the Science, Space and Technology, Subcommittee on Research and Technology, hearing to review the priorities of both the United States Fire Administration Assistance to Firefighters (FIRE) and Staffing for Adequate Fire and Emergency Response (SAFER) grant programs. The current authorization for USFA and the FIRE/SAFER programs expires on September 30, 2017. These grants provide resources and training to our nation’s first responders combating and preventing fires in our communities and we will work hard to extend their funding.

So far in 2017 the House has passed 8 bills, 3 specifically passed today, dealing with prevention of sex trafficking, children exploitation, and treatment for victims of trafficking. Legislation like this is not always mentioned in the day’s headlines but they are examples of bipartisan collaboration to deal with some of the most troubling issues of our communities. Trafficking has caused so much hidden trauma and I am proud of the strides we are taking to combat this issue.

Congratulations to my good friend Rep. David Valadeo on the passage of his bill, HR 23, Gaining Responsibility on Water Act. This bill, which I cosponsored, sets a timeline for completion of the New Melones Reservoir study, prevents federal and state exploitation of water rights, and extends the program to protect Anadromous Fish in Stanislaus River for 2 years. Californians understand the importance of reserving our water supplies for our neighbors.

Here is my floor speech from yesterday in support of my colleague, Rep. David Valadeo’s Gaining Responsibility On Water Act or GROW Act. Californians need to be proactive with our water supply to prevent future droughts. I am proud to have stood with my colleagues to help pass this important legislation.
Please stay informed here of any updates regarding the Towsley fire.

Today we passed the National Defense Authorization Act, authorizing programs to the Department of Defense through FY2018. This includes the largest pay increase in 8 years for our service members at 2.4%. Now we are able to provide our armed services with resources and advancements they have needed for a long time.

Last week my Women’s Business Center Legislation passed with the NDAA. Check out this op-ed I wrote, along with Antonella Pianalto, President and CEO of Association of Women’s Business Centers, about the Women’s Business Centers and their impact on our future women entrepreneurs.

Yesterday was the 100th Anniversary of NASA Langley’s establishment- the nation’s first aeronautics laboratory. Over the years, NASA has lead the way in aeronautics, technology, and space exploration. We are very lucky to have organizations like NASA who will work towards our future opportunities of exploration.

Today on Capitol Hill, I visited Pratt & Whitney's display of their newest turbofan engine. Its advances in fuel usage, emissions, and noise level reductions are rooted  in early stage R&D done in partnership with NASA and other U.S. industry players. This engine is the end-goal of two decades of American ingenuity and hard work, but it can't be where we stop. Foreign competitors are racing to catch up. We have to recommit to a disciplined R&D strategy to maintain our technological lead in aviation.

Senator John McCain is a true patriot and American hero. Throughout his life, he has continuously proven to be fighter and I know he will fight this too. He is a leader, advocate, husband, father, veteran, and much more. Lily and I have Sen. McCain and his family in our thoughts and prayers tonight.

"That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind." #OTD July 20, 1969, Neil Armstrong took the first steps on the moon. Apollo 11’s successful mission is a great example of American exploration and exceptionalism. It taught our nation of endless opportunities of exploring the unknown and never backing down from a challenge.

Monday, I had the great honor of touring Plant 42 with Air Force Secretary Heather Wilson and other Air Force senior leadership. We visited Lockheed Martin and Northrop Grumman, two defense contractors that exemplify the defense industry’s dedication to our national security and technological advancement, as well as Stratolaunch’s innovative efforts at the Mojave Air and Space Port. I am always proud to share the great impact the Antelope, Santa Clarita and Simi Valleys make on American safety at home and abroad, and look forward to advancing future opportunities for our district.

Yesterday, my staff presented a certificate of recognition for Urbane Café as the honoree this week from the Simi Valley Chamber of Commerce. As busy as they were, the friendly staff greeted each customer as they walked in, welcomed them to the restaurant and offered a specialty or crowd favorite (their delicious Cranberry Brie sandwich). Proud Manager, Ricardo was surprised and excited to share the certificate with his hardworking staff. Small businesses like Urbane Café keep our community unique and thriving!

Last night Lily and I had a great time at the annual Civ-Mil BBQ. This amazing organization does so much for the men and women and the families at Edwards Air Force Base. Thank you to Al Hoffman and the board of directors for all you do!

Saturday the Ventura County Star ran an op-ed I wrote with House Committee on Science, Space, and Technology Chairman Lamar Smith regarding small business legislation I introduced. Continuing the support of our Small Business Innovation Research and Small Business Technology Transfer programs are important so our local businesses have the opportunity to research with technological innovation and expand their product reach. Read the full article here.

My bill, the Small Business Investment Opportunity Act of 2017, passed the house unanimously yesterday! This bill is one of an ongoing effort of mine to increase available funding for entrepreneurs to expand their business reach and hire more employees. Read the full release here.

Last night I had the honor of speaking to a great group of students participating in the Reagan Foundation DC Summer program! This is a wonderful program for young college students to intern in Washington, DC and get real world job experience on the hill and with many organizations throughout the city in a bipartisan manner. These students were engaged in the conversation and are sure to be great leaders. Their political futures are bright! Thank you to the Ronald Reagan Foundation and Institute for all you do for the Reagan Library and Museum in Simi Valley and for your work to encourage and teach students the importance of civic engagement.

Russia, Iran, and North Korea have all presented legitimate threats to our national security. Time and time again, they have taken actions against their own citizens, threatened the lives of our allies abroad and Americans here at home. Today, led by a bipartisan 419-3 vote, the House passed one of the most expansive sanctions packages in history against these three nations on behalf of international safety. I thank my colleagues for their willingness to work together and protect global stability.

Today, my bill the SECRET act passed the House of Representatives with a unanimous vote! This piece of legislation will require an annual report on the backlogs of security clearances for workers dedicated to national security needs. This legislation, once enacted, would provide Congress with a report to hold the executive branch accountable in transparency and cut through bureaucratic red tape. Below is my floor speech from today on the SECRET Act.

Yesterday, a member of my staff presented Corner Bakery with a certificate of recognition for being awarded the Simi Valley Chamber of Commerce Restaurant of the week. Corner Bakery in Simi Valley provides great food and quick service to all customers in the community. Thanks for providing for our neighbors

Happy National Intern Day! I am honored to have such a great group of bright interns with such promising futures. Here I am with our summer interns; Rory, Jordan, Elle, and Joey. Their time in my office is coming to a close as they make their way back to their colleges for the Fall Semester, but their time with us has been a blast! These are hardworking young adults ready to jump into their future careers! If you or someone you know is interested in interning in our DC or District Offices, please visit my website! #NationalInternDay https://knight.house.gov/forms/internships

Yesterday marked the 64th anniversary of the United States, China, and North Korea signing the armistice agreement, ending fighting in the Korean War. This was a devastating war that reminds us of the current dangers we face still. There are still over 7,000 American soldiers unaccounted for and thousands of American lives lost. We remember the lost and hope for peace.

My staff attended the grand opening of the William "Pete" Knight Veterans Home Hobby Room. This room will be used by the residents for art classes and art therapy as well as other artistic mediums. The residents are thrilled to have the opportunity to express their artistic creativity.
#OTD July 29, 1958 President Eisenhower signed into law the National Aeronautics and Space Act, establishing NASA. Since then, NASA has been a leader internationally in space exploration and flight.

Earlier this week my staff attended the Henry Mayo wound care open house. These are the only 2 Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy Chambers in SCV. Patients will spend 90 mins 5 days per week for 6 to 8 weeks inside the chambers. The hospital reports a 90 % healing rate for patients. Great care for our community!

Today I attended a ceremony awarding Christian Hotz Jackson with the Eagle Scout Rank and Badge. Christian is part of Troop 499 of Stevenson Ranch. It is always an honor to be a part of ceremonies like this one that celebrate our remarkable young people. Congratulations Christian on this accomplishment!

Saturday Lily and I had the great honor of attending the first “Service Before Self” award ceremony, awarded to Chief Master Sergeant Todd Simmons, USAF at the Lancaster JetHawks vs San Jose Giants game! This event was hosted by Operation Gratitude, an organization dedicated to providing services and support to our service members. Before the game, we got to build teddy bears that provide comfort and love to children who have parents deployed overseas. Chief Simmons is the Command Chief for the 412th Test Wing at Edwards Air Force Base. This award was well deserved for all of the hard work and service Chief Simmons provides for our Armed Services and nation as a whole. Congratulations Chief Simmons and thank you to Bank of America/Merrill Lynch and Operation Gratitude for such an amazing event!

Do you know what the House has passed so far in 2017? If you’re relying on the news, you may not be as up to date as you think… Congress has focused on passing legislation that supports defense, care for veterans, and addresses issues like human trafficking and opioid addiction. Check out DidYouKnow.gop for more information on what we have passed and what we are working on next!

Having the Olympic Games return to Los Angeles in 2028 will be a great honor for our community. These games are a tradition of international unity and competition. They will bring business and opportunity to our area. I look forward to welcoming athletes, their families, and leaders from across the world to Southern California!

Not since Ronald Reagan's presidency, have we had a large overhaul of our tax code. This has been hurting our businesses and families across the country from achieving the "American Dream". The time is now to do something about it! Soon the House will be moving forward now on pro-growth tax reform that will grow jobs and paychecks nationwide, make the tax code simpler and fairer for all Americans, and help middle-class families – not Washington special interests.

Today we celebrate National Eagle Scout Day. Only about 4% of Boy Scouts earn the medal and designation of Eagle Scout and there are more than 2 million Eagle Scouts since its origin in 1912. Some notable Eagle Scout recipients are Neil Armstrong, President Gerald R. Ford, Bill Gates, John Garamendi, U.S. Senator Bill Bradley, and many more. This award is a distinguished honor of service to self, nation, and world.

Last week Lily and I attended an event honoring Valley Oasis, a community based non-profit agency in the Antelope Valley whose mission is to end social and domestic violence and homelessness through education, intervention, prevention, safe shelter and supportive services. A very special thank you Nichole McCracken and the event committee for a successful event and thank you to the Valley Oasis staff for all they do for our community!

I started my morning today at Crazy Otto’s meeting with many of the veterans in the Antelope Valley. I had the pleasure of participating in the presentation of an award to Woodrow “Pete” Randolph for his service in Vietnam. Pete also served in WWII. Thank you Pete for your service and congratulations on this well-deserved honor!

Wouldn't it be nice to be able to file your taxes on one sheet of paper the size of a postcard? Taxpayers pay a combined $99 billion a year filling their individual income tax. Our tax code needs to be revised so Americans can control more of their annual income.

Yesterday was a busy day. After breakfast with local veterans I headed to the Blackbird Air Park to learn about the Junior Test Pilot School Summer Museum Program. This is an 8 week program that is designed for students to learn STEM principles using the aircraft specifications, experiments, and advances at Edwards Air Force Base and Plant 42 in Palmdale.  It allows kids from 5-18 to learn about aerodynamics and meet pilots and engineers from our local area. I had a great time talking with the kids, their parents and the staff and interns. Thank you to Danny Bazzell, General Manager of the Flight Test Historical Foundation and the city of Palmdale for providing these amazing opportunities for the students of the Antelope Valley.

Lily and I joined many other community leaders and members at the Antelope Valley Hispanic Chamber of Commerce monthly lunch. It was great seeing so many friends and hearing about the great things that Habitat for Humanity, SAVES Foundation and Metal Health America are doing for the community.

It was a pleasure to join Veterans from both Palmdale and Simi Valley today! I started first for breakfast at Birdies Restaurant in Palmdale and lunch at PC's Bar & Grille in Simi Valley. This is such a great group of local veterans in our communities. It is always fun to listen to their stories and even tell a few of my own!

Congratulations to Aaron Kavanagh, an educator at Quartz Hill High School and Palmdale constituent, who is in DC this week participating in Summer Teacher Institutes at the Library of Congress. Mr. Kavanagh is a teacher in the Social Studies Department as well as the head basketball coach! During the five-day program, participants work with Library education specialists and subject-matter experts to learn effective practices for using primary sources in the classroom, while exploring some of the millions of digitized historical artifacts and documents available on the Library’s website. Excited to hear what you’ll be bringing back to our classrooms!

Wouldn’t you like to keep more of your paycheck? Congress is working on legislation to reform our tax code to make it easier for you to achieve your American dream. The foundation of our nation is based on opportunity for all Americans. It’s time to uphold to that.

Today I had the pleasure of attending the Antelope Valley College’s Aircraft Fabrication & Assembly Rapid Training Program. This program is a great partnership between AVC and local community partners. Cohorts of 24 students take classes in compressed 8 week sessions, gaining valuable hands on training in aircraft fabrication while earning transferrable college credits. The program is rigorous with students spending well beyond 40 hours per week in this classroom and lab setting. With two cohorts, classes begin at 6:30 a.m. and end at 10 pm, six days per week. The program has a 90% job placement rate. I enjoyed meeting Ray Disepio at the open house. He will be graduating in couple of days. Congratulations to Ray and the other graduates and thank you to AVC and Ed Knudson for providing this program for our community.

Yesterday I attended the Thunder on the Lot Appreciation Ceremony in Lancaster. Thunder on the Lot and its collaboration with Kids Charities has served our community with 22 years of incredible help to children suffering from domestic violence by proving abuse prevention therapy and many other services to disadvantaged kids of our community. Thank you to Ron and Yvette for all they do for this community and contacts on another successful year of service.

The U.S. economy added a strong 209,000 jobs in July and the unemployment rate fell to 4.3%, matching a 16-year low. Congress is working hard to create jobs and grow our economy. Regulations have burdened our small businesses for too long and we will continue to decrease those regulations so our businesses can grow and create more job opportunities for our communities.

Last night I attended the ribbon cutting of SAGE (Space and Aeronautics Gateway to Exploration) Academy in Palmdale.  This is another great School that is preparing our students for the future. I am looking forward to hearing about all the great things these students will do in the future!

Today I had the honor of witnessing Martin Spann receiving a Bronze Star with “V” Device (Valor) for his heroism on March 11, 2005 in Iraq. Col. Spann saved the life of an Iraqi soldier while under fire from insurgents. Major General Gravett was on hand today to present the award to Col. Spann. It was an honor for our office to assist Col. Spann in obtaining this important medal.
The new Palmdale Aerospace Academy school is open! The community came out and gave a warm welcome on a bright and beautiful day. Here come our future astronauts, engineers, and fabricators.

Yesterday I attended the 22nd Anniversary Memorial Ceremony of the passing of Simi Valley Police Officer Michael F. Clark who gave the last full measure of devotion to the citizens of Simi Valley when he responded to a "Man With a Gun" radio call. Officer Clark left behind a young marriage, a six month old son, an extended family, many friends and his comrades. He took with him the love of those mentioned and the enduring gratitude of our community. I am pictured here with Simi Valley PD, Chief of Police, David M. Livingstone.
Congress is working to simplify the tax code and make it more fair for everyone! Tax reform is needed now.

Lily and I joined the Palmdale Water District Board of Directors and Aqua Dog as the kicked off their year long 100 year celebration. Be sure to check their website for exciting events happening each month culminating with a huge celebration next July!
I had a great time meeting with the folks from Salem Media Group in my Simi Valley Office.
Last night I had the great pleasure of announcing the sponsors for the jazz concert featuring Jeanette Harris and Gerald Albright. Great show and a great night out in Palmdale.

Manufacturing has been a pillar of our nation’s economy. Made in America products are having to move overseas because of burdensome tax regulations. This is one of many reasons we will be working to fix our tax code so our companies can remain profitable and provide job opportunities here at home.

Today, we honor National Purple Heart Day. Purple Heart Medals are awarded to those wounded or killed while serving in the United States Armed Forces as a result of enemy action and also given to military personnel who display bravery and valor as prisoners of war and while fighting certain types of domestic terrorists. We thank all our service members who have been awarded this medal and remember the fallen.

Thanks to the Ahuja family for stopping by my DC office today! The Ahuja family are in town from Santa Clarita and are exploring all the historical sights the city has to offer. I hope you enjoy your visit!

This morning in Santa Clarita I met with local women – owned small businesses from all over the district. I heard from about their concerns, needs and issues to see how my office can better serve them. I shared details about the legislation I have passed and the bills I am working on now to help small businesses. As Chairman of the Small Business Subcommittee on Contracting and Workforce it is important to make sure that small businesses have “seat at the table” and have their voices heard. Thank you to everyone who came out and participated!

I am deeply saddened by the news of three marines who lost their lives in the MV-22 Osprey incident off the coast of Australia. My thoughts and prayers are with their families and loved ones. Their sacrifice will never be forgotten.

Yesterday my staff and I visited with Simi Valley Hospital CEO & President Jennifer Swenson and her executive team. We discussed the future and what changes need to be made in order to continue to providing the greatest care for our communities.

American businesses now spend roughly $147 billion each year on filing tax returns. That’s billions of dollars our small businesses and entrepreneurs could be spending on creating new jobs and growing their businesses in our communities.  Tax reform will give them the relief they need to grow and thrive.

Interns in our DC office were happy to show the Devine family around the Capitol today! The Devines are here from Acton on a family vacation. Sorry I missed you in DC but I hope you have a great visit!

Yesterday morning my staff attended the weekly Coffee4VETS at Crazy Otto’s as they do each week. If you or someone you know is having challenges with the VA please contact our office or visit our website’s veterans portal for more details https://knight.house.gov/benefits-portal/veterans.htm

I started my morning today with some of our local heroes at the Antelope Valley Veterans Community Action Coalition meeting at Birdies in Palmdale. It was good to hear from the City of Palmdale about the housing and programs they are providing for the veterans here in the Antelope Valley

Today I met with Airbolt Industries, Inc., a family owned business with 13 employees, operating in their new 7,000 sq ft facility here in Santa Clarita Valley. They manufacture aerospace components and are very happy with the support they've received from Santa Clarita since making the move. I was happy to learn about the products they build and opportunities they have provided our community. Small businesses like these are what grow an economy and expand our job force at home.

Yesterday I attended the Golden State Freeway (I-5) Roadway Rehabilitation Project groundbreaking ceremony. The Cal-Trans project will repair 16 miles of Roadway that is over 50 years old and will continue to provide transportation to and through the Santa Clarita Valley. This is part of an ongoing effort to repair our roads to make them safer and more reliable.

Staff attended the Ventura County Sheriff Geoff Dean's third annual Sheriff's Foundation luncheon. The Sheriff's Department’s ongoing mission is to keep our Ventura County communities safe. As always, the stars of the event were our amazing K-9 dogs who not only protect civilians from danger, but also protect our officers while on duty.

Yesterday I met with Antelope Valley Board of Trade’s Aerospace Committee. I gave a short update on current and pending legislation such as my bill, the SECRET Act, that will help with the backlog of security clearances. Thank you to Don Rhea and Al Hoffman for their leadership.

I am honored to have been awarded the U.S. Chamber of Commerce annual Spirit of Enterprise Award this morning. This award is given in recognition of support for pro-growth policies in Congress. Lily and I enjoyed the ceremony and speaking with local business owners and community leaders. Thank you to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce for this recognition.

Today, my staff attended the American Red Cross, Northern Valley Chapter "Celebrating Humanitarian Leadership Mixer". Executive Director Raul Claros is hoping to establish stronger connections and build new partnerships in the Antelope Valley and we are happy to join in their mission.

Yesterday my staff attended the Hillview Middle School Flag Raising Ceremony in honor of being recognized as a 2017 Gold Ribbon School. Congratulations to the Westside School District and the Hillview Hawks on achieving this important recognition!
My staff also attended the Ribbon Cutting Ceremony for Five Star Painting. Ms. Rachna Sharma just opened the store on August 1, 2017 and already had a room full of happy customers!

By fixing the tax code, families and small businesses will have the ability to plan expenses ahead of time and save for growth in the future. I look forward to working with my colleagues on the House Small Business Committee in achieving these goals through tax reform.
We must unite as Americans against racism and hatred.  My thoughts are with Charlottesville and, as always, the law enforcement officers keeping the peace.

Today staff attended the Eagle Scout Ceremony for John Bystrom. John lost his father three years ago and through the support of his church family and the scouts, John has achieved a remarkable feat. The ceremony took place at St. Peter Claver Parish in Simi Valley. John's final project was to build a viewing stand for his sister's riding stable. Congrats to John and his family on this much deserved accomplishment.

Today, staff members had a visit to Simi Valley Samaritan Center. The Samaritan Center provides services to Simi Valley’s homeless population. They also have a food pantry run primarily by volunteers. Staff had a tour from the Program Administrator and spoke to their in-house case manager about the programs the center offers and local efforts to combat homelessness.

I was fortunate enough to attend the AV Veterans lunch! This is a great group of veterans who meet on a weekly basis to discuss the community and relationship with the VA. My staffer, Chris Ward was recognized for all of the amazing hard work she has done to help our local veterans, many of which were in the room today. They thanked her for her help in acquiring records, benefits, and medals for their service. I am proud to see the good my office does for this community and congratulate Chris on this wonderful acknowledgement.

Thank you to Spectrum News for a great interview! We discussed North Korea and readiness. I expressed the important role our local aerospace and defense industries will play in protecting our country. We must protect our country from evil.
Racism and hate have no place in our country. Period. Neo nazis, white supremacists, KKK, and others alike speak and act only of hate and should never be defended.

Yesterday I hosted a Law Enforcement round table with representatives throughout my district. We had a productive conversation about arrest rates and continuing to expand efforts to protect our communities. One main component of the conversation was regarding the increase in drug abuse and how it is effecting every aspect of our neighborhood safety. I look forward to working with them further to combat these issues.

It was an honor to be a part of the legislative panel today for SRAR and local realtors. I was joined by Senator Wilk, Assemblyman Acosta, Supervisor Barger, and Mayor Smyth. We had a great discussion about federal, state, and local efforts to help home owners and buyers in our communities. Thank you to SRAR for having us!

Small businesses are important contributors to our local economies. We shouldn't be making it harder for them to succeed. As Chair of the House Small Business Subcommittee on Contracting and Workforce, I understand the complex tax policies that put more stress on our businesses. I look forward to working with my colleagues to re-examine our tax code and lessen these burdens.
Devastating news coming out of Barcelona today. We must stand together as one world to fight against terror. My thoughts and prayers are with the victims and the country of Spain.

Yesterday I visited Jaxx Manufacturing in Simi Valley, which is a family & friends owned contract electronic manufacturer and designer of components. The company was started in one of the owner's garage 25 years ago and has grown to now employ 99 workers. They are in the process of developing their own line of avionics products and plan to become a manufacturer in their own right.

This afternoon Lily and I joined the Hispanic and Palmdale Chambers to celebrate the 20th Anniversary of Sam’s Silkscreening in Palmdale. Sam and his family are an integral part of the Antelope Valley after starting in the garage and now has built it into a thriving business. These are the stories that make us all proud to be Americans. Congratulations Sam!
Happy Solar Eclipse Day and welcome to our new Fall Semester Washington, DC interns! Were you able to watch this morning?

Thank you to Meggitt for allowing me to lead an important discussion today about women in aerospace! We have to bring all of our best and brightest into the talent pool. This means reforming our education and training systems, and strengthening the programs in place that are already improving the recruitment and engagement of women and minorities. Thank you to all of the Meggitt staff who attended and shared their experiences and institutional knowledge on the importance of expanding women's roles in aerospace.

Yesterday I visited the Simi Valley City of Hope Care Center. I met with Dr. Bahareh Bahadini M.D. who has been leading the Center's efforts to provide a full range of Hematology and Oncology care. Thank you for welcoming me to your facility and providing the care you do for the community.

Today a bipartisan bill that updates the disability claims appeals process at the Department of Veterans Affairs, the Veterans Appeals Improvement and Modernization Act of 2017, was signed into law. This reform will ensure our veterans receive timely responses to necessary care through the VA.

On this day, 50 years ago in 1967, the fastest man that flew set the ultimate speed record of Mach 6.7 in an X-15. I am lucky enough to have called that man my dad. Dad was very proud of all the work the U.S. Air Force and X-plane program accomplished at Edwards Air Force Base. Yes, it's true it has been fifty years and the absolute air speed record in a manned aircraft is still 4,520 mph, but the resolve of the American people is burning bright and our thirst for new records and new challenges has to be quenched. I am so proud of my father and his achievements, but I am most proud of his willingness to take a risk and try to push and understand that the sky is no limit.

I enjoyed participating in the House Science, Space, and Technology Committee's hearing today "Powering Exploration: An Update on Radioisotope Production and Lessons Learned from Cassini". We discussed restoring the U.S.’s ability to produce the radioactive material that power spacecraft that help us push the boundaries of human knowledge and better understand the origins of our universe. Comprehensive tax reform is long overdue, and the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act will help grow the economy, create jobs, and expand opportunities for everyone. By reducing federal tax rates at every income level, this bill will allow Americans to keep more of their hard-earned income. I fought hard with my colleagues from California to secure a deal on State and Local Tax deductions to retain the ability to use these deductions and to provide more flexibility to households who itemize their taxes. Additionally, the strengthening of the Child Tax Credit, relief for expensive medical bills, improving savings vehicles for education, and providing support for graduate students will help families in every part of America make ends meet. January 11 is National Human Trafficking Awareness Day. Human trafficking is a modern day form of slavery affecting millions in the United States and abroad. We must work to protect those that are harmed by this terrible practice, which is why I am proud to stand with Representative Ann Wagner from Missouri in cosponsoring the Trafficking Survivors Relief Act. Tragically, victims are commonly charged with crimes such as conspiracy, money laundering, drug trafficking, tax and immigration violations, prostitution, and related offenses that follow them throughout the duration of their lives. This bipartisan legislation would allow victims of human trafficking to petition courts to vacate convictions and expunge arrest records for offenses that they were forced to commit as victims of trafficking. The bill does not cover violent crimes or offenses of which minors were victims, and it gives courts discretion to decide whether convictions should be vacated. I look forward to working with colleagues to take a huge step toward relief for victims of human trafficking.

As a husband to a nurse, I’ve seen firsthand the challenges families and patients face under our current health law, which is why today I voted in support of the American Health Care Act.  I believe that our nation’s families deserve a healthcare system that is affordable and sustainable, not just for the next five years, but for generations to come.  The reality is that the Affordable Care Act is failing across the country by making care more expensive and in many places, severely limiting choices.  It’s not just failing in other states, it will eventually fail in California too. Action is required right now to replace its most damaging aspects before many families have no choices at all.  I am pleased that the House adopted an amendment I authored that would ensure that individuals with pre-existing conditions are protected in every situation for every family, in every state, especially California.  I have strongly advocated for and promised this throughout the entire discussion. This is a good first step, and I look forward to working with my colleagues to offer solutions that will address the problems faced by our current system and allow Americans access to the care they need.

Thanks to the House Natural Resources Committee for unanimously passing my bill, HR 2156, the St. Francis Dam Memorial Act. This bill is widely supported by our community and I am proud to be a part of an effort to commemorate the lives lost because of this tragedy.

Today is PTSD Awareness Day. Please join me in raising awareness on this tragic disorder that affects thousands. This is a threat to the lives of our soldiers and victims of many crimes that truly adds additional challenges to how a person operates on a day to day basis. My bill, No Hero Left Untreated Act, which passed the House last month, aims to offer more treatment options. If you or someone you know is suffering, please seek help immediately.
